Erich was diagnosed with multiple myeloma. He outlived the initial prognoses by several years but succumbed in 1995.
The final campaign took up most of his later years: in particular, his work for IPPNW and founding and fighting the World Court Project.
abortion law reform, humane treatment of psychiatric patients, proper health funding, zero population growth, and nuclear disarmament.
This led to a life of campaigning. He fought for: sex education, cervical smears, a 2nd medical school, the contraceptive pill,...
He founded the NZ Medical Association as a rival to the NZ branch of the British Medical Association, & started publishing his own journal.
He did not like the conservatism of the NZ medical community and he set out to change it and to fight for better medical services.
He left Otago and went to work in general practice in the Wellington region. My mother and he built a practice together.
While lecturing at Otago University, he also fell in love with one of his students, my mother.
He fell in love with New Zealand. He particularly loved the people here, their generosity and their spirit.
While in that role, Erich saw an advert for a medical research/lecturing job in NZ. He took a boat to NZ not knowing what to expect.
When his mother became sick, Erich left his research career to work in the hospital treating her. When she died he became a ship's surgeon.
Erich worked for while as a researcher at the forefront of medical science, particularly the science of ageing.
Erich was a Fulbright Scholar and spent some time travelling and studying in the USA.
He was naturalised as a citizen of the UK in Edinburgh in 1944. He developed a love of all things Scots including whisky and Burns.
He told me he enrolled to do a third doctorate at the Sorbonne in French literature, but that might have just been a joke.
During those 10 years, he published at least 16 publications in a wide variety of topics, not only medicine but also old French.
As a student of Edinburgh University, Erich completed a doctorate in medicine and then a second doctorate in pharmacology.
Erich lived in Edinburgh for 10 yrs. He completed his undergraduate medical degree then transferred to be a student of Edinburgh University.
Erich was granted a place in London School of medicine which, because of the Blitz, had moved to Edinburgh.
Erich taught biology in a private boys school while searching for a place in med school. It was there that he learned the rules of cricket.
Erich said the internment camp was wonderful, full of artists & intelligentsia, including the Amadeus Quartet who would perform.
When the war started, Erich was interred as an enemy alien for ~6 months.
The other sister went to the USA where she married the man who later invented the remote control. Erich and his mother went to the UK.
Sadly, it appears Martha was betrayed by her lover's husband. She was arrested & transported to Auschwitz where she was gassed on arrival.
Martha later travelled to the Philippians, then Spain and Italy, before returning to be with her lover in occupied Ghent.
Alfred arranged permission to enter the UK. But one sister, Martha, wanted to stay in Ghent. She had fallen in love with a married woman.
Erich & his two sisters made it to Belgium. They lived there for ~9 months. At some point their mother joined them.
Erich took a train to Berlin figuring that no one would look for a Jew fleeing in that direction. The next day, Hitler annexed Austria.
From the UK, Alfred tried to help the rest of his family escape.
Alfred’s work led to the Nazi’s calling for his murder. He was smuggled by Reuters over the Alps and to the UK.
Erich’s brother Alfred worked for Reuters. He went on to found Reuter’s business division. Alfred reported on the Nazi atrocities in Vienna.
Erich started his medical studies at the University of Vienna before all Jews were barred from the University.
Erich became a polyglot, learning most European languages, ancient and modern.
Erich developed a deep love of music & language. He told me stories of sneaking into Italian operas or listening to American music radio.
Erich grew up in his family’s café surrounded by discussions of the political issues of the day.
Erich’s father fought in the Austrian Imperial Guard in WWI & received an injury from which he never fully recovered until his death in 1930
Erich was born in Vienna. He was of Jewish decent. His father was socialists (so non-religious), but he grew up in the Jewish community.

Schlegelberger’s decision to remain in office as long as he did lent his good name, & thereby gave credibility, to the Nazi regime. (10/11)
Schlegelberger was sentenced to life for his "hesitant injustices" because of the inherent injustice of the system he applied and… (9/11)
Schlegelberger said he believed that if he resigned someone worse would take his place. This turned out to be right. (8/11)
Schlegelberger resigned in 1942 because "the cruelties of the system were too much for him.” (7/11)
Schlegelberger applied those laws with some leniency, although Hitler had the power to overrule lenient sentences which he exercised. (6/11)
Schlegelberger tried to resist, eg arguing that half-Jews shouldn’t be sent to the camps (if they would agree to sterilisation). (5/11)
The laws Schlegelberger applied were the laws in force as passed by the national authority of the time, the Nazi Party. (4/11)
Schlegelberger refused to join the Nazi Party until he was ordered to do so in 1938 by Hitler. (3/11)
Schlegelberger was a respected jurist, an author, a law professor, and a judge. He rose to Director of the Reich Ministry of Justice. (2/11)
This seems like a good time to tell again the story of Franz Schlegelberger, one of those tried in Nuremberg after WWII. (1/11)
